metadata.title: What will happen? — Predict Future Business Using a No-Code AI Model and Microsoft’s AI Builder. | by Sebastian Zolg 🤝 | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: What will happen? — Predict Future Business Using a No-Code AI Model and Microsoft’s AI Builder.
metadata.description: AI Builder, as part of the Microsoft Power Platform, allows business users to create apps with AI functionally - without any coding skills.

all_paragraphs: AI and Machine Learning are big words and often hidden behind a massive technology stack and a sophisticated set of skills acquired by people from various backgrounds.
Recently, we see a lot of market movements to democratize these technologies and thus making it available for everyone, regardless of their coding or data science skills.
Of course, Microsoft is in this game too.
AI Builder — as part of the Microsoft Power Platform — might not yet be the most well-known feature, but it is for sure one of the most thrilling ones.
It allows business users to create apps, enriched with AI functionally without any coding skills or other data science related knowledge.

The solution is spanning the wider context of Microsoft’s Power Platform and Dynamic 365. It further natively integrates into Common Data Services (What is CDS?), which gives it an immensely powerful ecosystem.
The current release of AI Builder supports a wide range of prebuild AI Models as of today:
Furthermore, AI Builder gives you the option to train your own AI Custom Models using these AI model types:
The high-level process of building AI models with AI Builder is straight forward and quite simple.

You configure your model with existing data and train it. After that, you verify the model performance and do some quick tests. Once the model is ready, you publish it. From that point on, you can consume the model in many ways and in various places. You could use it inside of your business workflows or within mobile apps, to name just a few.
Let’s look at one of the AI custom models in more detail: Prediction.
The Prediction Model allows us to predict business outcomes by using historical data with historical outcomes.
In other words: It allows training and testing of a Machine Learning Model with absolutely no code and no background in math, statistics, or any other data science related fields.
Here is everything we need for our own AI model:

Let’s assume we’re working for a bike sharing/rental service company, and we have a bunch of historical data telling us a lot about past rental numbers and the exact weather conditions that day. Furthermore, our data contains information about weekdays, holidays, and other interesting facts.

Our goal is to build an AI model that can predict the number of potential rentals a day given a set of input variables, expressed by the weather forecast, overall season, and upcoming holidays or weekends.
We’ll work with a slightly modified version of a data set taken from UCI Machine Learning website and stored on my GitHub repository.
Let’s go step by step through the creation process of our AI model.
First, go to https://make.powerapps.com, select Entities, and click Get Data.
From the list of sources, click Text/CSV.
Next, enter the URL to the bike-sharing.csv in my GitHub repository to directly crawl the data from there.
After the data has loaded, it is important to note the cnt #(count) column, which represents the number of bike rentals that day. This is the so-called feature we would like to predict.
Note that the first ten entries have a cnt of null. We’re later using those entries to test our trained model right after.
Before we go ahead, we must change the type of the instant column to text, so we can later use it as the primary name field. This becomes important when we want to override/replace entries.
Click Add new step when prompted and then click Next.
On the Map entities form, we finally model the Bike Sharing Record. Configure everything according to the screenshot and click Next.
Select Refresh manually and click Create.

Back on Data, hit the refresh button of your browser, so the newly created Bike Sharing Record Entity shows up. Make sure you’ve selected Custom from View option on the upper right corner. This way, you find your customer entities much quicker.

On the Data tab of the Bike Sharing Record, make sure you’ve selected the Custom fields view from the Select view drop-down. You’ll immediately see our data and again spot the first ten entries where we have no value for the cnt feature.
We’ve now imported an entity and a bunch of data to train the AI model. Let’s begin.
Now that we have our data ready, we go to AI Builder > Build and select the Prediction model.
Give the new model a proper name like Bike Sharing Prediction and click Create.

Let’s look up our Bike Sharing Record Entity from the Entity drop-down and select the cnt feature from the Field drop-down. This is how we tell the AI Builder which feature we want to predict. Click Next.
On the next screen, we select all features we want to use to build the model.
Note that some fields are already excluded. This is because system fields created by CDS, like Created On can skew prediction results, so they are excluded by default.
Furthermore, not all data types are shown. Our model can study numbers, currency, date, two options, option set, and text data types.
The rest of the selection is up to you and part of your business domain knowledge. For our data set, we rely on the documentation of the original data set and choose the following fields.
Of course, you could choose a different combination and see if you can get better results. We will later see which of the variable drives the prediction most. Click Next when you’re ready.
We skip the filter step and click Next.
Now it is time to do a final review. Click Train when done and wait for the model to be trained.
Carefully watch the progress in the Status column. Click the model when its status changed to Trained.
Here it is. 🚀 Your first AI model build with AI Builder.
You can see the performance of your model and which variable drives it the most. The model is good but not perfect. It leaves us room for improvement, but this is part of another story.

After you reviewed everything, you just need to click Publish. This process will publish the model to production and immediately starts the prediction on all entries with null values in the cnt column (the first ten).
To see what the model predicted, go back to Data > Entities and click the Bike Sharing Record.

On the Data tab, make sure you select the Custom fields view and look for the first ten entries. The cnt field is still empty, and this is by intent. The predicted values are not stored in the original field. Instead, three additional columns are created. Look for the one named xxx_cnt-predicted and notice the numbers there.
The prediction is the number of bike rentals we can expect on a day like this.
Congratulations! 👏 You’ve created your first model with AI Builder and predicted the number of potential bike rentals based on several conditions.
From here we could do the following:
But we keep this all for the next story.

I’m an IT professional with experience in enterprise mobility, workplace, cloud technologies, and software development. sebastianzolg.de
